Agency is the capacity to act.


Decentralizing Agency increases this capacity by distributing it among those we trust — formalizing feedback loops and social support.


As a collective, we deploy this framework to work on tangible and speculative projects that do not aim to be commercially viable but instead shape viable futures.

The Why Paper Use Framework
  • Substack ↗
  • Discord ↗
  • Colophon

Ground Rules

Last edited and agreed upon by all members at 17th of December, 2020.

Collective

1. We work on the viable futures we all need, while trying to break with the self-destructive tendencies we all have.
2. We operate as cooperation rather than corporation.
  a. Meaning every member is co-owner with equal voice and vote.
3. Any action on behalf of us, or affecting us has to be voted on by all members.
  a. Members generally can vote “for,” “against,” or “neutral.”
  b. Voting happens openly on Discord by emoji response to proposals.
  c. Actions can only be taken when no members are “against” them.
4. Agreed upon actions don’t obligate members to be hands-on involved with them.
5. Even without hands-on involvement, all members can always voice their opinion.
6. Credit is given where credit is due.
  a. Those hands-on involved in projects get due-credit.
  b. If profit is involved, this is divided based on hands-on involvement.
  c. Profit division is agreed on project by project basis, and ahead of time, by those hands-on involved.
7. Part of any profit from our activities goes towards a collective fund.
  a. The fund is in service of further increasing our collective capacity to act.
  b. The fund can fuel new projects, events, donations, investments, and more.
  c. Ratio of profit to go to fund is defined by all members ahead of activity.
  d. Using the collective fund is a collective action, requiring a vote (rule 3).
8. We assume members apply mutual understanding and respect.
  a. Assume good intentions from each other.
  b. Argue in good faith.
  c. Always feel free to question and critique each other.
  d. Always feel free to question and critique the collective as a whole.
  e. Framework and ground rules are open to change through rule 3.

Membership

9. New members can be proposed by existing members at any time.
  a. A proposed member is voted on by collective vote (rule 3).
  b. An accepted member is invited to meet us and our rules.
  c. An invited member can join for a trial period before accepting the invitation.
10. New members are assumed to share our goals (rule 1), and to wish to put work into achieving them.
11. Membership is not contingent on any metrics of activity or participation.
12. Members are always welcome to house projects with us, but are not obligated to do so.
13. Pursuing a project on behalf of Decentralized Agency requires a vote and adheres to rule 3 and subsequent rules.
14. Members can always request help on non-collective projects.
  a. But transparency is key.
  b. And clear communication is expected, i.e. is it a paid project, will they be sharing credits or profits, etc.
15. Members are free to exit the collective at any time.
16. Member removal can only happen with proposed reason and unanimous vote.
  a. Member in question can make their counter-reason before voting occurs.
  b. Member in question does not participate in vote.
